description: Number of numbers m with Euler phi(m) = n.
comments: Carmichael conjectured that there are no 1's in this sequence. - _Jud McCranie_, Oct 10 2000Number of cyclotomic polynomials of degree n. - _T. D. Noe_, Aug 15 2003
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, section B39.
J. Roberts, Lure of The Integers, entry 32, page 182.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
K. Ford, The number of solutions of phi(x)=m, arXiv:math/9907204 [math.NT], 1999.
S. Sivasankaranarayana Pillai, On some functions connected with phi(n), Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. 35 (1929), 832-836.
Primefan, Totient Answers For The First 1000 Integers
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Totient Function
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Totient Valence Function
formula: Dirichlet g.f.: Sum_{n>=1} a(n)*n^-s = zeta(s)*Product_(1+1/(p-1)^s-1/p^s). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 12 2003lim_{n->infinity} (1/n) * Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) = zeta(2)*zeta(3)/zeta(6) = 1.94359643682075920505707036... (see A082695). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 12 2003
mathematica: a[1] = 2; a[m_?OddQ] = 0; a[m_] := Module[{p, nmax, n, k}, p = Select[ Divisors[m]+1, PrimeQ]; nmax = m*Times @@ (p/(p - 1)); n = m; k = 0; While[n <= nmax, If[EulerPhi[n] == m, k++]; n++]; k]; Array[a, 92] (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Dec 09 2011, updated Apr 25 2016 *)
prog: (PARI) A014197(n,m=1) = { n==1 && return(1+(m<2)); my(p,q); sumdiv(n, d, if( d>=m && isprime(d+1), sum( i=0,valuation(q=n\d,p=d+1), A014197(q\p^i,p))))} \\ _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 05 2009
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
